title-group.article-title: Keratin sponge/hydrogel: I. Fabrication and characterization

article-meta.aff: USDA ARS – Wyndmoor, PA, USA ERRC

author-notes.corresp: Jeanette M Cardamone, USDA ARS ERRC - Wool and Keratin-from-Wool Research, 600 East Mermaid Lane, Wyndmoor, PA 19038, USA. Email: jan.cardamone@ars.usda.gov

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Keratin sponge/hydrogels formed by oxidation and reduction hydrolysis of US domestic fine- or coarse-grade wool exhibited distinctively different topologies, each with unique porous structure. These materials retained amino acids and microstructure as protein homologues of intact keratin. Amphoteric character was confirmed by differential dyeing with anionic and cationic dyes. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) provided evidence of molecular organization and the behavior of occluded moisture through measurements of glass transition, peak temperature, thermal degradation temperature, enthalpy of water removal, and degradation (Tg, Tw, ΔHw, Tt, and ΔHt). The absence of denaturation peaks indicated highly crosslinked molecular association. Low ΔHw indicated high plasticity and the ability to absorb and retain moisture. Small amplitude strain analysis rheology to measure storage or elastic modulus, G′, and shear loss or viscous modulus, G′′, as a function of applied strain characterized the sponge/hydrogels as covalently crosslinked networks. With viscoelastic properties typical of both liquids and solids, they maintained their structural integrity under strain.

body.p: Keratin was extracted from wool by oxidation and reduction hydrolysis of wool to form 40–60 kDa solid keratin protein in the form of sponge/hydrogels. Keratin comprises up to 95% by weight of wool. It is chemically reactive through amino, amide, sulfoxide, sulfide, thiosulfide, sulfhydryl, phenolic, guanidine, imidazole, and carboxyl, cystine (-S-S-), and cysteine (-SH) residues. The two-phase composite structure is composed of partly crystalline, alpha-helical intermediate filaments (IFs), embedded in an amorphous matrix of 10–12 nm Type I and Type II super-molecular protein aggregates which are arranged in α-helix, β-sheet molecular motifs.1 This molecular architecture confers strength and rigidity to conformations of globular, functional keratin found in solubilized keratin hydrolysate. As the main biological material of human animal protein, keratin is useful in a wide range of biomaterials applications where peptide-based biomaterials are preferred for topical products, injectable matrices, bone regeneration scaffolds, and nanofiber platforms.2,3 Keratin structural protein is easily crosslinked and/or combined with other biopolymers to improve tissue function. It has the major advantage of ease of availability and high versatility as a biodegradable biomaterial for tissue engineering to function for use in regenerative medicine. Natural protein keratin was biocompatible scaffold for fibroblasts and osteoblasts owing to its cell adhesion sequences of arginine–glycine–aspartic acid (RGD) and leucine-aspartic acid-valine (LDV).4–6 Scaffolds in tissue engineering have taken the form of hydrogels as macroporous polymer gels with porous gel walls and large voids. These materials are of significant interest from the fundamental and applications point of views, particularly for biotechnological and biomedical applications. Prosthetic human-hair-keratin devices for implantation have been made from keratin hydrogel to replace gel-filled silicone envelopes and saline-filled breast implants.7 Self-assembling peptide hydrogel scaffolds are becoming a popular material choice for a variety of engineering applications including drug delivery, cell culture, and tissue regeneration. Macroporous hydrogels prepared by freeze-drying can exhibit a broad variety of porosities. They are formed with different morphologies and textural networks characterized by individually distinct swelling and mechanical properties. A hydrogel platform with highly controlled release kinetics has potential applications in cellular responsive drug delivery.6–8 Hydrogels can swell and release antibiotics to the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, for example, amoxicillin and metronidazole in enzyme-free simulated gastric fluid (SGF, pH 1.2) and simulated intestinal fluid (SIF, pH 7.2) at 37℃.9

sec.title: Preparation of keratin sponge/hydrogel
sec.p: Carbonized and scoured US domestic fine wool, 1½" staple length, ∼60s, ∼21 µm from Rambouillet Merino sheep (Bollman Hat Company, Adamstown, PA), and coarse wool, ∼8′ staple length, ∼40 s, ∼34 µm from Lincoln sheep (Wool Hollow Farm, Jericho, VT) were hydrolyzed. Oxidation hydrolysis proceeded by in situ formation of the hyper-peroxide, peroxycarboximidic acid, formed from a composition of dicyandiamide (CAS 461-58-5), C2H4N4, 84.08 g/mol (Aldrich); gluconic acid, potassium salt, 99% (CAS 299-27-4), C6H11KO7, 234.5 g/mol, (ARCOS); Triton™ X-114 (CAS 9036-19-5), C30H54O9, 558.75 g/mol, (SIGMA); sodium hydroxide (CAS 1310-73-2), NaOH, 40 g/mol, (Fisher Scientific); hydrogen peroxide, 50 wt % solution in water, H2O2 (Sigma-Aldrich); and urea >99.5% CH2N2O, 60.06 g/mol (Fluka).10 Reduction hydrolysis proceeded with the action of 2-mercaptoethanol, 99% (CAS 60-24-2), C2H6OS, 78.13 g/mol, (Aldrich), urea, ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid tetrasodium salt dehydrate (EDTA), 98%, 416.21 g/mol (Aldrich), and sodium dodecylsulfate (lauryl) (CAS 151-21-3) (Pierce).

Hydrolysis was carried out individually in 500 ml (20:1 liquor ratio) with stirring in a temperature- Lab-Line Orbit Environ Shaker Bath controlled to 60–65℃. After treatments, the keratin materials were centrifuged using a Sorvall RC-5B Refrigerated Superspeed Centrifuge at 2℃, 12,000 rpm for 30 minutes to isolate solid keratin sponge materials and residual hydrolysates. These materials were filtered, dialyzed through 6–8 kDa MWCO Spectrum Spectra/Por membrane, recovered, and washed and stored in dilute ethanol. Sponge/hydrogel was formed after oxidation with 3 g/l dicyandiamide, 3 g/l potassium gluconate, and 50% H2O2 at 60℃, pH 9–11 within 4 hours with the appearance of a matted mass of fine fibers taking the form of a firm sponge (ARS DD). Sponge/hydrogel was formed by reduction hydrolysis in a 6 M urea bath containing 2.0 M 2-mercaptoethanol and 0.1N NaOH, pH 8.2–8.7 at 40℃ within 4 hours with the appearance of a soft, firm, relatively homogeneous sponge with a smooth surface (M1-1).

Reaction pathways for solubilizing wool by oxidation and reduction involved cleaving wool’s disulfide bonds. In the oxidation hydrolysis of wool, ARS DD keratin was the product of vigorous alkaline-peroxide oxidation of –SH thiols giving keratin sulfonate products.11 Severe oxidation proceeded to form disulfide, thiosulfinate, thiosulfonate, disulfide trioxide, disulfide tetraoxide, and sulfonic acid forms: 2RSHthiol→sRSSRdisulfide→R(S=O)SRthiosulfinate→RSO2SRthiosulfonate →RSO2SORdisulfide trioxide→RSO2SO2Rdisulfide tertroxide H2O→2RSO3HSulfonic acid

M1-1 keratin was the product of reduction of wool with 2-mercaptoethanol, a mild reducing agent, to cleave disulfide bonds and generate thiols. In the presence of air, sponge/hydrogel formed by reformation of disulfide bonds. Specifically, free thiol interchanged with existing disulfide bonds to form new intramolecular and intermolecular disulfide bonds, giving form and structure to M1-1 sponge/hydrogel through reaggregation:12 R1S -SR2+R3SH→R1SH+R2S -SR3

sec.title: Amino acid analysis (AAA)
sec.p:
Amino acid content was determined by a method adapted from Cohen and De Antonis.13 Samples were hydrolyzed under vacuum for 24 hours in constant-boiling 6 N HCl at 105℃, reacted with 6-aminoquinolyl-N-hydrosuccinimidyl carbamate to form stable urea with fluorescence at 395 nm, separated using a 150 mm × 4.6 mm AccQ·Tag C18 reverse phase column (Waters Corporation, Milford, MA), and eluted with the gradient of acetonitrile and aqueous buffer described as ‘system 2’ in the reference. Sample peaks were quantified using a fluorescence detector set to excite at 250 nm and detect emission at 395 nm. The quantitative amino acid composition, expressed as mole percentage for each amino acid in Table 1 was determined by external standard calibration (Waters Corp. Amino Acid Hydrolysate Standard). Table 1.

Mole % Mole %/Cys M1-1 ARS DD

Ser 12.78 11.64 7.88 11.31 13.14 12.10 9.99 11.59
Glu 10.76 22.69 6.63 22.05 8.25 9.71 9.17 12.69
Gly 19.58 18.35 12.08 17.84 14.63 15.34 10.17 7.67
His 1.08 0.21 0.67 0.20 3.98 0.36 2.28 1.44
Arg 3.84 2.48 2.37 2.41 4.71 2.96 5.12 7.31
Thr 5.05 2.98 3.12 2.90 4.41 3.02 3.24 4.02
Ala 8.57 4.84 5.29 4.71 5.61 5.52 4.81 7.34
Pro 6.27 8.91 3.87 8.66 6.31 5.57 5.90 6.81
Tyr 6.12 0.99 3.77 0.97 5.22 3.87 4.09 3.04
Val 2.91 2.67 1.79 2.60 1.05 1.16 5.80 2.41
Met 0.00 1.74 0.00 1.69 1.36 0.35 1.24 0.32
Lys 2.79 1.69 1.72 1.65 0.41 1.72 2.26 3.03
Ile 3.46 7.19 2.14 6.98 1.63 2.33 1.59 1.85
Leu 6.35 4.91 3.91 4.77 5.70 7.26 6.46 8.13
Phe 2.12 1.98 1.31 1.93 2.52 1.95 2.14 2.41

sec.title: Dye uptake
sec.p: Amphoteric character was assessed by the absorption of anionic Acid Blue 25 (C.I. Acid Blue 62055) and cationic Basic Blue 5 (C.I. 21010) dyes. Dyebaths contained 3% dye (on weight of fiber) in 5:1 (fiber: water) liquor ratio baths. The dyeing procedure followed conventional time/temperature dyeing of wool without acid assistant. After initial 20 minutes of dwell at 30–60℃, the temperature was raised 2℃/minute to reach 90℃ for approximately 60 minutes for complete uptake of the dye in a neutral dyebath. Uptake of ionic dye indicated the native ionic character of the sponge/hydrogel materials. Comparison dyeings were made on untreated wool fiber having an assumed pI of 4.5–8.0. Colorimetric determinations were made on a BYK-Gardner color machine with Color-insights™ software with illuminant and observer conditions of D65 and 10°, respectively. The CIELAB (L*, a*, b*) color system was used to measure lightness, L*, and color strength, K/S. According to the Kubelka–Munk equation, K/S = (1-R)2/2R, K/S, is directly related to the overall color intensity of the samples, dependent on K, the light absorption coefficient, S, the light scattering coefficient, and R, the reflectance factor. Comprehensive color measurement concepts have been reported previously.14

sec.title: Morphological observations
sec.p: Samples on carbon adhesive tabs (Electron Microscopy Sciences, Hatfield, PA) were mounted on specimen stubs. Micrographs were recorded in a Quanta 200 FEG environmental scanning electron microscope (FEI Co., Hillsboro, OR) in the high-vacuum secondary electron imaging mode at an accelerating voltage of 10 kV. Digital images of selected fibers at instrumental magnifications of 1000 and 2500 were used to magnify the surface. Surface topologies were imaged at 10 × magnification in a light source box using a digital image analysis system equipped with a B/W CCD solid state TV camera (Hitech Instruments, Inc., Edgemont, PA) attached to a 35 mm camera interfaced with a camera control unit (Hitech Instruments, Edgemont, PA). Images were acquired and archived in a personal computer equipped with an Oculus-MCX B/W frame grabber board (Coreco, Inc., Quebec) for conversion to digital images using Image-Pro software (Media Cybernetics, Inc., Silver Springs, MD).

sec.title: Thermal analysis
sec.p: Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC) was used to determine thermal stability, water/evaporation (freeze/melt) temperatures, and enthalpies from representative thermograms. Samples of 10–35 mg each of dehydrated ARS-DD and M1-1 sponge/hydrogels were analyzed on a DSC (Q100, TA Instruments, New Castle, DE) within the range of –40℃ to 220℃, with a heating rate of 10℃/min. Each sample was placed into a high-volume stainless steel pan. Modulated DSC (MDSC) thermograms were recorded to illustrate relevant thermal events. MDSC conditions were as follows: –50℃ to 250℃, modulated ±1℃ with a ramp rate of 3℃/min.

sec.title: Rheology: viscoelastic properties (G′, G′′, and η*)
sec.p: Small amplitude strain analysis (SAOSA) with oscillatory motion at low strains was applied to stretch internal bonds for measuring the response of the material matrix to small-scale deformations. Viscoelastic properties provided information on the strength of the internal bonds holding the material matrix together. Sponge/hydrogel samples, 25.4 mm in diameter and 4–5 mm thick, were measured on an ARIS2000 rheometer (TA Instruments, New Castle, DE). A specimen disk was placed between two parallel plates and subjected to sinusoidal oscillation. Strain was varied harmonically with time to measure G′, the elastic or storage modulus, a measure of solid-like behavior, G′′, the viscous or loss modulus, a measure of fluid-like behavior, and η*, the complex viscosity, a measure of viscoelastic flow in the linear viscoelastic region. The linear viscoelastic region of each material was found by strain sweeps over a frequency range of 0.1 to 100 rad/s. All samples were tested at 0.8% strain, which was found to be well within the linear viscoelastic region for each material.

sec.title: Texture profile analysis (TPA)
sec.p: TPA analysis with large destructive shear was applied to compress the matrix for measurements of hardness, cohesiveness, and springiness and response to deformation to indicate overall strength and construction for testing at 25℃ on a Universal Testing Machine (MTS Systems, Eden Prairie, MN, USA., Four replicates were tested for each sample. Samples were cut to cylindrical plugs (∼14.5 mm in diameter and height), placed between parallel plates, and compressed by 75% twice using a crosshead speed of 100 mm/min and a 50 kg load cell. Hardness is the amount of force required to compress the specimen the first time, springiness is the percentage the specimen recovers after the first compression, and cohesiveness is the ratio of the area of the second force-time curve to that of the first. Hardness (somewhat analogous to shear stress) was used to measure the strength of the protein matrix. Cohesiveness indicated the strength of the internal bonds. TPA is a common test in food analysis and is used to measure compression and recovery of a material. Unlike G′ and G′′ measurement the specimen remained intact after analysis.

sec.title: Morphology and structure
sec.p:
The microscopic structure of native wool is distinguished by surface scales which protrude above the surface of the fiber, as shown in Figure 1(a). After hydrolysis to cleave disulfide bonds, keratin structures of various physical forms, as shown in Figures 1 and 2, were isolated. Soft, amorphous structures formed after reduction hydrolysis and disulfide bond reformation, as shown in Figure 1 (b) and Figure 2(a, b). Mat-like material formed after oxidation hydrolysis (Figure 2c and d). From investigations of keratins extracted from wool by reduction hydrolysis and by alkaline hydrolysis, Cardamone showed that the chemical compositions and secondary structures of the new products were similar to original wool.15 Figure 1.
Structures: (a) natural wool fiber; (b) keratin sponge/hydrogel formed by reduction hydrolysis of (a).
Figure 2.
Keratin sponge/hydrogels formed from fine and coarse wool fiber: (a) M1-1 from coarse wool; (b) M1-1 from fine wool; (c) ARS DD coarse; (d) ARS DD fine.

sec.title: AAA
sec.p: The functional composition of amino acids in gram equivalents per 105 g of keratin protein, was reported as 58–66 free carboxyls, 79–98 amide, 137–164 carboxyl plus amide, 22–36 phenolic hydroxyl, 124–148 aliphatic hydroxyl, 78–92 total basic, 20–24 amino and 27–43 aromatic nuclei available for coupling with diazonium salts: tyrosine plus histidine, 92–114 half-disulfide (cysteine, -SH), and 526–650 oxidizable units, contained as the constituent amino acids of keratin polypeptide.16 In our work, keratin from reduction and oxidation hydrolysis of wool showed the constituent reactive amino acids in Table 1. Dialysis was effective for retaining 6-8 kDa keratin fractions with the loss of lower MW constituent peptides, therefore the results of AAA analysis in Table 1 are qualified in this manner. From Table 1, for every Cys unit, the units of Asp, Ser, Glu, Gly, Ala, Pro, Ile and Leu, are relatively high in coarse wool.

Cys (combined cystine and half cystine) was higher in the oxidative samples consistent with oxidation cleavage of disulfide to form sulfonated products which do not reform disulfide bonds. Asp, Ser, and Gly were highest in the reduced sample. Lys and Glu are significant for transamidation reactions where in situ microbial transglutaminase (Tgase) can link protein, non-protein, and enzymes by covalent bonding through Glu and Lys amino acids. Tgase transamidation proved to control the dimensional stability of wool with the inference that keratin can self-crosslink and crosslink to proteinous substrates such as body tissue and to a variety of Gly–Lys carboxamide-active agents.17–19 Met and His content in fine and coarse wool are so low they cannot be measured accurately.20 Dusenbury reports that Met and His have the lowest amino acid residues in fine and coarse wool: 0.7–0.6 g Met/100 g dry wool, 0.9 g His/100 g dry wool, compared with 11.3–9.2 g Cys/100 g dry fine and coarse wool.21 Differences in high/low values for fine and coarse wool in the three data sets can be attributed to the lack of chemical homogeneity of the wool fiber and the stability of fine versus coarse wool to chemical attack.21

sec.title: Dyeing characteristics
sec.p:
Evidence of amphoteric character was shown by absorption of anionic Acid Blue 25 and cationic Basic Blue 5 dyes. Deep dyeing, shown by low L*(lightness) and high K/S (dye uptake, overall color), indicated the ionic character of the keratin sponge/hydrogels. Native wool fiber with high L* and low K/S was consistent with low dye uptake. Hydrolysis formed charged, chemically reactive sponge/hydrogels, receptive to the absorption of ionic dyes through acidic amino acids Asp and Glu and basic amino acids, Arg, His, and Lys. The amphoteric nature of M1-1 sponges from coarse wool was shown by highest dye uptake of Acid Blue 25 and Basic Blue 5 in Figure 3. The anionic character of ARS DD coarse with greatest affinity for Basic Blue 5 was consistent with the characterization of sulfonation by oxidation. Figure 3.
Relative comparisons of lightness (L*) and color strength (K/S) indicating the extent of dye uptake of keratin sponge/hydrogels after dyeing with Acid Blue 25 and Basic Blue 5.

sec.title: Thermoanalytical behavior
sec.p:
Native wool reportedly exhibits a step glass transition temperature (Tg) of 160–175℃ when dry, 50–60℃ when wet and –5℃ in water. There is a bimodal melting endotherm of α-form crystallites in wool fiber at 230–240℃ with degradation from the domains of ortho- and para-cortical cells or from the overlapping of the melting endotherm of α-form crystallites and the thermal degradation of other wool histological components where polar and ionic network and water content is affected by liquefaction of the partially crystalline structure. 22–29 The thermoanalytical parameters of keratin sponge/hydrogels dependent upon water content were interpreted from Tg, glass transition temperature, Tw (℃), melting or freezing point (peak temperature of water), ΔHw (J g−1), enthalpy needed for water removal, Tt (℃), thermal decomposition temperature, and ΔHt (J g−1), enthalpy needed for thermal decomposition in Figure 4. Figure 4.
DSC thermograms of sponge/hydrogels formed by oxidation and reduction hydrolysis of wool fiber: (a) ARS DD from oxidation of fine wool; (b) ARS DD from oxidation of coarse wool; (c) M1-1 from reduction of fine wool; (d) M1-1 from reduction of coarse wool.

All keratin sponge/hydrogels, except ARS DD coarse, showed the absence of decomposition peaks indicating that -S-S- bonds, H-bonds, and salt links remained stable throughout the heating cycles. M1-1 with relatively high Tg was characterized with high molecular association. ARS DD coarse sponge/hydrogel with low Tg was descriptive of a plasticized structure. Heat evolved by the fusion of water within the hydrogels was calculated from the recorded DSC thermograms by integrating the endothermic melting peaks. The DSC thermograms of keratin sponge/hydrogels exhibited prominent, sharp endotherms for water transitions at low temperatures (Tw). Negative Tw indicated the association of ARS DD keratin with freezing bound water and positive Tw for M1-1 samples indicated weak association with non-freezing bound water. Corresponding high enthalpy (Hw) for M1-1 sponge/hydrogels and low Hw for ARS DD sponge/hydrogels for water removal was further evidence of the much higher plasticity of ARS DD compared with M1-1. We inferred that ARS DD samples possessed greater capacity to absorb and retain imbibed water and that water was more tightly bound in the M1-1 keratin sponge/hydrogels. The decomposition peak at 164℃ and relatively low Tg for ARS DD coarse distinguished this material with unique morphology.

sec.title: Rheology: viscoelastic properties (G′, G′′, η*)
sec.p:
Viscoelastic properties were found by applying strain to force molecular deformations caused by the sliding propensity of keratin’s microfibrillar structure. The overall elastic responses of the keratin sponge/hydrogels are shown in Figure 5 where the curves illustrate the behavior of micro- and macromolecular, associated, fibril matrix. Water-swelling influenced supramolecular deformation of the microfibril matrix network. With applied strain, water was ejected to compress matrix proteins between microfibrils to elicit viscoelastic responses.30–35 In viscoelastic response to strain, stretching and sliding with breakage of disulfide bonds impeded molecular slippage and the structures remained intact, presumably without losing supermolecular order. SAOSA showed that all keratin sponge/hydrogels behaved like viscoelastic solids with conformation and structure described in terms of storage modulus (G′), loss modulus (G′′), and complex velocity (η*) as a function of frequency of oscillation. Figure 5.
Rheology, dynamic tests: elastic modulus (G′), viscous modulus (G"), and complex viscosity (η*): (a) M1-1 fine; (b) M1-1 coarse; (c) ARS DD fine; (d) ARS DD coarse. Note: Arrow designations for G′ values where the sponge/hydrogel begins to break down occur at frequencies of 50, 50, 39, and 32 radians/second, respectively.

Keratin sponge/hydrogels contained phases of randomly connected membranes and voids which could be followed by changes in applied strain. Here G′ and η* were indicative of bulk, effective viscosities, and pore deformation. When small deformation oscillatory strain was applied and G′ and G′′ measured, no entanglement effects were observed because a G′–G′′ crossover to show liquid-like character at low frequencies and solid-like character at higher frequencies was not observed. Rather, G′ and G′′ were parallel. Typical mechanical behavior was expected for covalently crosslinked networks G′ with a plateau and G′′ with a considerably smaller value. With applied strain, the stored energy, G′, for the breakdown of solid-like behavior (indicated by the arrows in Figure 5) decreased in the order: 1 M-1 fine > 1 M-1 coarse > ARS DD fine > ARS DD coarse. The G′ values demonstrated that the M1-1 sponge/hydrogels exhibited approximately twice the stored energy of the ARS DD sponge/hydrogels, which showed that the crosslinked network had higher strength, toughness, and stability. These results showed that the microstructural elements in M1-1 sponge/hydrogels exhibited greater agglomeration or clustering than those of the ARS DD sponge/hydrogels. The approximately “zero” value of slope G for all sponge/hydrogels indicated that in the viscous regions, the energy dissipated with strain remained constant, although M1-1 values were a third higher. All keratin sponge/hydrogels exhibited viscoelastic properties with strong and permanent covalent networks with little frequency dependence when subjected to small deformation oscillatory strain.

sec.title: Texture profile analysis
sec.p:
Cohesiveness, hardness, and springiness were measured by applying force to collapse the pore structures and cause molecular chain overlap. The coefficient of variation for hardness, springiness, and cohesiveness were below 10% for each sample. The sponge/hydrogels recovered approximately 75% of their original height after compression to first touch, causing the layers to weakly interpenetrate. Cohesiveness, the unit-less ratio of the area of the second force-time curve to that of the first, indicated how effectively the structures held together after being compressed. Values of 0.57 to 0.73 were considered high when compared to crumbly cheese with typical values of 0.1–0.2.36–38 Hardness, the force required to compress the sample, was greatest for ARS DD coarse sponge/hydrogel, thus having the greatest resistance to deformation. All other keratin sponge/hydrogels were also highly cohesive but softer in Table 2. Table 2.
Texture profile analysis of keratin sponge/hydrogels from oxidation and reduction hydrolysis of wool: cohesiveness and hardness
Treatment Cohesiveness Hardness (N)
M1-1 fine 0.60 12.7
M1-1 coarse 0.57 6.5
ARS DD fine 0.73 6.0
ARS DD coarse 0.67 46.1

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Keratin sponge/hydrogels from reduction and oxidation hydrolysis of wool were distinctly different in appearance and behavior. Those formed by reduction hydrolysis appeared smooth, soft and firm, homogeneous, and malleable with no well-defined features. Those formed by oxidation hydrolysis were well-defined, structurally integrated entanglements of finely agglomerated microfibrils with the overall appearance of mat-like platforms. All retained keratin amino acids, ionic character, and intact microstructure, which indicates the potential to function as stand-alone biomaterials or as precursors for subsequent modifications. They differentially and characteristically were capable of absorbing cationic and anionic species because they exhibited the preserved amphoteric character of native wool. The porous nature of the ionic sponge/hydrogels influenced thermo-mechanical responses to moisture. Narrower endotherms of M1-1 sponge/hydrogels indicated faster response to water loss at higher peak temperature and higher enthalpy for stronger association with moisture. The water in sample M1-1 fine was strongly bound, accounting for the difference in freezing point depression. The onset of molecular mobility at higher glass transition temperatures for M1-1 samples suggested stronger molecular association than ARS DD samples. ARS DD sponge/hydrogels with broader isotherms at lower temperature indicated weaker association with moisture. Viscoelastic response at lower strain for ARS DD indicated a relatively looser microfibrillar, consistent with their structural appearance. M1-1 sponge/hydrogels were stronger, tougher, and more stable with highest break-down (G’) values from applied oscillatory strain and could be classified as high viscosity liquids whereas ARS DD sponge/hydrogels were distinguished by complex viscosity (η*) as less viscous, with greatest ease of movement (fluidity). The classic behavior of keratin sponge/hydrogels as agglomerated biomaterials formed from oxidation and reduction hydrolysis was to function as solids or liquids. They were highly ionic protein species of different physical forms which were chemically reactive and responsive to mechanical strain without degradation. These mechanically stable and potentially reactive materials can function as stand-alone or modified platforms.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge Adam Myers for technical support, Michelle Hall for amino acid analysis, and Audrey Thomas for DSC data.
